turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: I'll call them and tell them you're taking your time. Being a professional.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Okay, call them. Fine. Oh-- And if you could find out why they double- booked the job, and who is trying to kill me, and call me back-- that's be great.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: Will do.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I bought a new rug.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: That's wonderful, Mom.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What's a revival tent?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's a place where religious people--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Marlin Perkins and Jim!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Jim?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: His assistant. He acted like Marlin's son, only he wasn't. At least they never said he was... I bet they were lovers, faggots. Yes, gay lovers. Wild Kingdom my ass!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's good to see you. I'm sure you're curious about what I've been doing.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I spoke to your father the other day.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I imagine that'd be rather difficult.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nature made him then broke the mold.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: They told me you're taking lithium, mom.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, they give me headaches. I have a headache.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You have a headache?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I have a headache. You have a headache?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No, I don't have one.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You don't have a headache. I have a headache.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We had a good laugh, didn't we?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yeah. I guess we did.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why don't you return this car and borrow mine? Have Debi follow you to the rent-a-car so you can get a ride back.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I think I'll go see Debi today.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Of course you will.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I can't think of anything to say to her that seems appropriate given I left and never said goodbye to her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Take care of her. She's a keeper.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And a leader. Didn't she meet Castro on foreign exchange?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I have always thought about her and missed her.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Marty! It's me. Paul.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Paul?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You're leaving me hanging here...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: So what happened to you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Same thing that happened to you-- I stopped poutin' there on the sidelines. Got in. Got on the team. I joined the working week, you slick fucking asshole, so why don't you valet park your high horse and take it easy on your old buddy, Paul.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Fair enough.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: God it's great to see you.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You too.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Debi's house.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Kind of crept up on you, didn't it?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No. You drove us here.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, but it's still kind of eerie, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Ten years. What happened!?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I freaked out, joined the Army, worked for the government, and went into business for myself... I'm a professional killer.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: He sells BMW's?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He sold me this bad boy.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: How could you put your hard-earned dollars into the hands of the class bully?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He gave me a great deal.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Mein Dealer.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What the hell happened to you?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I was catching up with Bob Destephano.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: As long as you had a good time.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It didn't work out.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I have to get my head back into my work.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Work's good for the soul.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: When you see Debi, tell her I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: See you in ten years.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: So when are you authorized to use deadly force?

turns.speaker: SOUTHTEC GUARD
turns.text: Well, a 'course, taxes provide your basic service-- police and whatnot. But our customers need a little more than just that, you understand? This badge doesn't mean that I am a peace officer.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: So it's not a meaningful symbol, or anything. That badge is just the badge of your company. If I look suspicious on your customers' property-- well, under those heightened circumstances you have the authority to, ah... To shoot me.

turns.speaker: SOUTHTEC GUARD
turns.text: To shoot you. Correct.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: How did you get this job?

turns.speaker: SOUTHTEC GUARD
turns.text: Well, they were hiring, and it was only a two week course...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Wow.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Good evening, Mr. Newberry.

turns.speaker: MR. NEWBERRY
turns.text: Good evening, Mr. Blank.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: How are you? How's business?

turns.speaker: MR. NEWBERRY
turns.text: Martin, I don't know where you've been since you abandoned my daughter ten years ago, and I don't care. It was good that you left, and I'm glad you did. So what do you want to talk about? You've grown up a bit. Maybe I had you figured wrong.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: MR. NEWBERRY
turns.text: I visualized you, in a haze, as one of the slackster, flannel-wearing, coffeehouse-misanthropes I've been seeing in Newsweek.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I took the other road. I'm more of a self-reflective young lion who does business with lead-pipe cruelty and goes home to drink light beer in milky-eyes isolation. I love sports and sex and have no real relationships with anyone. And you?

turns.speaker: MR. NEWBERRY
turns.text: Oh, you know me, Martin. I'm the same old sell-out baby-boomer, exploiting the oppressed I got shot for at Kent State. But why don't we have a drink and forget the whole thing?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MR. NEWBERRY
turns.text: So what are you doing with your life now, son?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'm a professional killer.

turns.speaker: MR. NEWBERRY
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: This is Annie MacLean.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yeah. Hello. This is Tom Booker. I got a message you called.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I went on the Internet and found this article about you... It says you're a Horse Whisperer, that you... you help people with horse problems. And you have quite a success rate when it comes to traumatized --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, see, truth is, ma'am, I help horses with people's problems.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, you know, however you want to put it -- I got your information from the publisher of the article. I called Montana and your sister-in-law, I think, gave me this number.  I'm been hot on your trail you could say because I was hoping you'd consider coming to New York and taking a look at my daughter's horse and possibly --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ma'am, I'm very sorry about your problems and I appreciate what your daughter must be going through, but I'm afraid you've misunderstood whatever it is you read. I don't do that sort of thing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, if you could just come for the day. New York's only a few hours by plane, I'd have you home by dinner...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Look, even if it was nearer, that's just not what I do. I give clinics. And I'm not even doing them for a while. I'm heading back to Montana right now. I got a ranch to take care of...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'll pay you for your fare. I'll send you to Montana first class.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ma'am, first class to Montana is a waste of good money. Now, am I being too polite here or when I say NO in Utah, does that mean YES in New York City?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I, I don't mean to sound insensitive. I understand your situation. But there's nothing I can do. You just called the wrong person, that's all. I hear there are a bunch of therapists in New York. Maybe you should call one of them.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Mr. Booker, if I could just ex --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I am very sorry, ma'am. Goodbye now.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's, uh... beautiful country. I had a little bit of a hard time finding the place. There are no signs.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Plenty of signs -- just none of them printed. Who do I get the idea you're not just passing through!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well... OK... here it is... Uh... I'd like you to take a look at my horse. Now -- it won't take long and if, after that, you still don't feel...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Were you thinking of personally driving me back East?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh no. She's here. I brought him along. And my daughter, too. We're staying at Peterson's...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You mean you hauled him all the way out here? Just like that?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well... yes... I had a trailer. It's not like I made him run along side of the car.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: All by yourself?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I uh... ha, ha... I don't think I ever met a lady quite like yourself and I appreciate all the pains you've gone through to --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Look! Please! Don't do the "shucks, ma'am" thing again!  I've driven a few thousand miles for a few minutes of your time. I've brought him here -- to your neck of the...  -- mountains. Just take a look at him. If you still feel the same way, I'll be on the road by morning and you'll never see me again. OK? Deal?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Uh, no. I was gonna take a look now.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You want us to come with you? I just have to run to the main house and give Mr. Peterson a check.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Grace?... Grace, you want to come with us, take a look at Pilgrim?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: When I work with a horse, it's no good just me doing it. It doesn't work that way. The owner needs to be involved too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, that'll be a little complicated --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You can make it as complicated or as easy as you like. But she's the one who's gonna be riding him, am I right? So here's the deal. I'm not sure I can do anything, but I'm prepared to give it a go --  -- if you'll help.  You have a problem with that?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Look, I'll talk to Grace and call you later--

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Excuse me, with all due respect, but this is her decision, not yours. And I don't want to waste anybody's time -- mostly mine.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't have a problem with that. It's up to Annie.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, it's worth it, really? I mean, how much longer do you think you need to work with Pilgrim?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That's up to Pilgrim.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You know, we're branding here tomorrow. If you two want to come by to watch or give a hand, you're welcome.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Branding?  I haven't branded in years.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It is cocktail hour yet?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: So how was your first and last day of branding?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't be so sure it's my last. There are a few people back home I'd like to put under a red hot iron.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You ever just stand still for a minute?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You stand still too long in New York you get hit by a bicycle messenger.  You know, sometimes, I get the feeling, Mr. Booker, that you're laughing at me. Why is that?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's your cue to say you're not laughing at me.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Oh, I see, you write both sides of the conversation?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's a man's world, Mr. Booker. Most women have to.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, maybe I am laughing a bit... I just thought, as long as you're here, it would be nice for you to relax into the place a little.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well... It's beautiful country, I'll give you that. And I could see having some kind of vacation place. Retreat. But I don't know how you do it full time. Don't you miss the rest of the world?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What's that to miss?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Ha... if you've never lived in a city with museums, theater, music, restaurants, uh... god, a million things, then it's something I can't explain.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Does Chicago count?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You lived in Chicago?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: When I was first married.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You were married to a woman in Chicago?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I once heard Itzhak Perlman guest star with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. He played Rachmaninov's Vocalize Opus 34. No. 14. It was one of the most beautiful pieces of music I ever heard. I actually forgot where I was for a time.  You seem surprised?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I, uh... you didn't...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Just who's been laughing at who here?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I've decided it's impossible to properly say hello in this place without a hat.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: A jogger, huh?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't jog, Mr. Booker. I run.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Lucky for you. The grizzlies around here only go for joggers.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: If I can survive rush hour, I figure I can handle grizzlies...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You sleeping all right in that house?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't sleep all right anywhere. But the house is fine.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I found this old cello case filled with bills and receipts.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Sorry about that. I thought everything got cleared out. R.B. is my wife... ex-wife... Rachel. We used to live in that house together.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I thought you lived in Chicago?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I thought you were an editor, not a reporter?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I have a way with animals.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: It's all right. He's young. Just hold out your hand a little lower so he can get the smell of you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh yes. I forgot.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He's beautiful.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Why don't you ride anymore? Grace told me you used to ride when she was younger.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: She did?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Are you shy, Mr. Booker?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Just polite. Well, maybe you'd like to try riding again, some time before you go home.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Enjoy the day.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Need a lift?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I can handle it!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The answer's no.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You haven't heard the question yet. Truth is, you'd be doing me a favor. I got all these eager young colts need riding and poor old Rimrock here is feeling kind of left out...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Poor thing.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: He'd be grateful, he'd take real good care with you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Is this how you're going to make me pay my phone bill?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No, ma'am, I'm afraid that's extra.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Relax our center... It's just sitting in a bucket.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, it's been a while, but I... I remember the basic ideas...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: OK. I'll stop talking then.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Actually, I never rode Western. I'm sorry. Go ahead.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, he don't know that. Just sit the horse.  Good... You have a nice seat.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Feel good?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You look all right. You want to pick it up a little?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How long did you live here with your wife?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Five years. My son was born here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Son?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yeah. I haven't seen him in a while. He used to come to the ranch over summers, but then he started having friends and was going off to college, so... Good boy. Hal. Lives in New York near his mom.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How did you meet her?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: College. In Illinois. She was playing the cello. I hadn't heard cello music growing up. She had the reddest hair, the bluest eyes. When she played, it was...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why didn't it work out?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: She was never really happy here. She did the best she could.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Grace told me you have a country house in Connecticut. Sounds like a beautiful place.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It is. It's lovely.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ever think of moving there full time?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: We did at one point. When we thought we'd have more children. And we after tried. We tried everything, but... wasn't meant to be.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I hear that! See, I knew she was never going to be a ranchest, but I wanted to try -- I thought maybe she'd give music lessons to the kids in town or at the school, maybe even recitals. My son would grow up here. Maybe have one or two more. I'd teach 'em what I could. They'd play with my brother's kids. All grow up together. And even if they all decided to go out into the world, they'd always know where home was -- cause we'd keep it for 'em...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's very important to you, isn't it? Home.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yeah, I think it is. And I don't mean everybody's got to be married, have kids -- It's more like, knowing where you're from, where you belong, what feeds you, where you can go no matter what happens... Knowing what you're supposed to be doing while you're here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How did you find out all that?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Everything under control?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Not really. I'd forgotten how long it's been since I've done this. And I couldn't get any Parmesan cheese.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Just make yourself comfortable.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I am comfortable.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ha, ha... all right, well, uh I guess you can bring out the pasta.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You missed a button.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: This is Mr. Booker, Robert.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Tom.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Now, listen. I want you to stand on him.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I won't apologize for this. And I won't hide it. Not for anybody.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I won't ask you to.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, God, what are we going to do? I'm supposed to --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ssshhh...  Stand still, Annie. Takes what we've got, just for now. Can you do that?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Show me again.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Annie!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: One more time.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Summers are short here, Annie. There isn't much of a fall. Before you know it, the roads are closed... the nights get long.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't care! We'd be together.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Two people can't just be alone together in the world. At least not us...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I can't do this. I can't leave you...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I figured, whenever you decided to go, you'd be all set.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How thoughtful of you. And what if I decide not to go?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't know any other way, Annie.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Then what have we been doing? I mean what was the point?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: The point was to love each other.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Liz is taking care of him.  The doctor said the sooner you start therapy the better the chances are you can --

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I can't even get out of bed yet! You're already putting me in therapy!!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why don't you go lie down?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I don't want to lie down. I've been lying down enough.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Dad'll pick you up today, all right?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, honey... What happened?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Doesn't matter. I... I don't want to come back, that's all.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh. Well, what are you going to do? You have to go to school, honey. I mean, what --

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I'm not coming back! That's it! I want to go home!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Grace, listen to me. Your body is just healing. You have to give the rest of you time as well...

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Is that your version of a pep talk?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You are not staying home all day feeling sorry for yourself. You're going to get up and you're going to figure this out.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Fine!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's still early. What's your next class?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I can't find that charm Daddy gave me from India.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I brought it to you in the hospital.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: No, you didn't.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Grace, I put it on the table near your --

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Have you decided about Pilgrim?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What about him?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well... how you feel all right about telling Liz to put him down...

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I think we should. It's not fair to let him suffer. He's not much use anymore. He'd hate living like that.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I think that's... very compassionate and... mature way of looking at it.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Mom?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Maybe they should put me down too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I mean, I'm not much use anymore. Why can't they be compassionate to me?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You want to take your bath?  We have to get up early tomorrow. You may not have enough time to --

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Fine -- I'll take my bath.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I don't mean you have to. It's just that we may not have enough --

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: -- enough time tomorrow. I know.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Look, if you want to take it in the morning, that's fine.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: IT'S ALMOST LUNCHTIME. ARE YOU HUNGRY!?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Whatever you want.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Fine!

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You should call your dad before it gets too late.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I already did.  This morning. When you went running.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh. You didn't tell me.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I didn't know I had to.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You don't.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Would you like to see that?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: This'll be nice. We haven't seen any of the sights yet. It's history. When I was thirteen I used to love seeing things like this.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You were never thirteen, Mom.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How long is this going to go on?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You know what I mean?  Is this it now? Is this the way we're going to be from now on?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Do you want us to turn around and go back home? Do you?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What are you asking me for? You didn't ask me if I wanted to come in the first place -- now I get to decide? Forget it!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Who do you think I'm doing this for? I'm doing this for you!

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Bullshit! It's about you! About you deciding! About you always being right! You always getting everything your way, controlling everybody -- like we work for you or something!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't believe this!

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You just want to get away from Daddy and you're using me to do it!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's not true! Whatever problems your father and I are having, have nothing to do with this.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You're amazing! You act like I don't live in that house! Don't you think I hear the two of you!? Don't you think I can tell what's going on? I'm not five years old, Mom!  You want to divorce Daddy and Daddy doesn't want to.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Did he tell you that?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: He doesn't have to! It's, like, so obvious you can't stand him.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's not true!

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Then why do you want to leave?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's... it's not that simple to explain. I know you think it is, but it's not. The truth is, I don't really know what I want to do. I don't have all the answers.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: No, you just act like you do.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You buckled up?  You cold?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Little.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Gee, this looks like a fun place.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't they believe in signs here?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What would they say? "Ten miles to big rock." "Twenty miles to bigger rock."

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: There was supposed to be a turn off. Did I miss it?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I didn't see it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He's still sitting in that damn field.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I think they call it a pasture.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: We'll have more room because we're moving onto the ranch. They have this empty house near this creek. It's actually pretty... OK... I love you.  Dad wants to talk to you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Did you ask him to come visit?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You already did.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Did he mention it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, he's going to think about it. You want me to pack for you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You got everything you need?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: If I had everything I need, I wouldn't be going to physical therapy.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Honey, come on. Would you like to stay in town for dinner? Maybe see what movie's playing tonight?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Why? There's no food in the house?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No. I just thought... forget it.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I'll come.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh, I don't, honey. Branding? Oooh... I think we'd just be in Mr. Booker's way.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I thought there were too many forks on the table.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, one was for salad...

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Mom, they don't mind eating with one fork.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You're right. Good.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Does anybody out there want something to drink?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I'll take care of it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thanks, honey.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Did you go riding?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Grace? Is everything all right?  Can we talk?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well...  So you tried riding again?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Yeah. Does that mean I'm cured?!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Honey, nobody's trying to cure you --

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: ... You worried everything all right now and we'll have to go home?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You... not wanting to go home because you hate daddy so much.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Grace, I don't hate your father.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I can't remember the last time you made him dinner.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I was just trying to say thank you to Diane and Frank and --

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Tom?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Look, I just wanted to say, I think it's great you're riding again. And... and I think I know why you, you needed to do it alone... without anyone knowing...

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Yeah, you know everything!!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: STOP IT! Why can't I talk to you!!

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: NO, YOU STOP IT! Stop pretending like you care! Like this really isn't about you and Tom.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: WHAT?! How can you --  I'm sorry if my friendship with Tom bothers you so much, but I happen to value having someone to talk to, especially when my own daughter ignores me night and day because no matter what I say, it's wrong and no matter what I do, it's wrong... I'm sorry I'm such a disappointment to you.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Well, now you know what it feels like.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't deserve that. I have never looked at you as a disappointment. If I'm on your back to do better, if I push you to try harder it's because I want you to be the best you can be.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: FOR YOU! Because I'm your daughter which means you're the best mother! Isn't that what you're always talking about in interviews -- having it all, the great career, the great family... Proving everybody wrong. Wanting everybody to think you're this perfect woman!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Listen, if... if there's a part of you as parent that... that takes pride in your child -- that, you can look at them and see something you've accomplished as well... if that's wrong, then I'm sorry.  But it wasn't my intention. I don't push for me. I do it for you... So you don't waste half your life feeling like you don't know where you belong.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Yeah, well, you've done a great job.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, then I do apologize... But what I'm most sorry for is turning you into a spoiled brat who can only think about what she's feeling... who can't admit when she's wrong and who can't forgive when she's not.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: LEAVE ME ALONE!!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I said... I started.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Started what?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: My period.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: When? Tonight?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I felt it happen downstairs and when I went into the bathroom.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Who's going to want me now?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?... Oh baby...

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Who's ever going to want me? Nobody will.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's not true.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Why should they?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Because you are... one of the most... incredible, bravest, most beautiful woman I have ever met. The efforts you make. Your courage and your dignity.  I don't know where you got it? I honestly don't know how I would have handled all this if I were you.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I'm sorry... about what I said. It's just that -- all those times you and Daddy were trying for another kid, I... I used to pray at night that it would work. And not because of you guys or that I wanted a brother or sister... but... just so I wouldn't have to be...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: So special. Because I was the only one. You both wanted me to be so good at everything, so perfect and I wasn't. I was just me. And now I've completely ruined everything, anyway...

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh, nothing. I'm going to pick it up in the other room -- would you hang this up for me?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Let's bring your bags inside.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Wait till you see this -- we have the whole house to ourselves...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What's the matter, honey? Gonna miss Pilgrim?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Tom's gone.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Smokey told me he left last night to look at some horses in Sheriden. He won't be back for three days. I can't believe he didn't want to say goodbye.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well... honey... you know... that's just not his way. Maybe you can write him a letter or something. Say thank you... Don't think about it... You take care and I'll see you home.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I miss you. You look beautiful.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: So do you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How's everything?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Great!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Go ahead...
